idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; Esri ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000

descript.abstract: United States National Atlas Water Feature Lines is a line theme representing the linear water features (for example, aqueducts, canals, intracoastal waterways, and streams) of the United States.
descript.purpose: United States National Atlas Water Feature Lines provides the linear water features for geographic display and analysis at regional and national levels.
descript.supplinf: Largest scale when displaying the data: 1:1,000,000.

citeinfo.origin: National Atlas of the United States and the United States Geological Survey
citeinfo.title: United States National Atlas Water Feature Lines, 2012

cntinfo.cntinst:
In the United States– Please direct all inquiries regarding software/data pricing and consulting services to your local Esri Regional Office. For support, you may contact Esri Support Center by telephone (voice) between 5:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Pacific time, Monday through Friday, by dialing 888-377-4575; facsimile (fax) available at 909-792-0960; electronic mail (e-mail) support@esri.com; or visit http://support.esri.com/; Esri holidays excluded.
Outside the United States– Please direct all inquiries regarding software/data pricing, sales, support, and consulting services to your local Esri Office. This information can be found at http://www.esri.com/about-esri/locations.html.
For other questions or comments, you may contact Esri headquarters by e-mail, telephone, or fax or write to us.

edom.edomvd: A structure designed to transport water from a supply source to a distribution point, often by gravity.

edom.edomvd: A stream or river that flows in an intricate network of interlacing channels.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States and the United States Geological Survey
edom.edomvd: An artificial open waterway constructed to carry water, to irrigate or drain land, to connect two or more bodies of water, or to serve as a waterway for water craft.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States and the United States Geological Survey
edom.edomvd: An artificial open waterway, that contains water part of the year, constructed to carry water, to irrigate or drain land, to connect two or more bodies of water, or to serve as a waterway for water craft.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States and the United States Geological Survey
edom.edomvd: A barrier constructed to control the flow or level of water.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States and the United States Geological Survey
edom.edomvd: A vertical or near vertical descent of water over a step or ledge in the bed of the river.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States and the United States Geological Survey
edom.edomvd: A system of rivers, canals and designated channels along the northern border and the Atlantic and Gulf coasts of the United States.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States and the United States Geological Survey
edom.edomvd: A body of water flowing in a channel or watercourse.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States and the United States Geological Survey
edom.edomvd: A body of water flowing in a channel or watercourse for part of the year.

digtinfo.formspec: The SDC file contains the geospatial and attribute data. The SDI file contains the spatial index. The PRJ file contains the coordinate system information (optional). The XML file (*.sdc.xml) contains the metadata describing the data set (optional).

stdorder.ordering: Data & Maps is available only as part of Esri® software.

citeinfo.title: National Hydrography Dataset

citeinfo.othercit:
The tiles were downloaded in December 2004.
This supplies the correct spelling of the Santiam River in Oregon.

procstep.procdesc:
This file was originally digitized by the National Mapping Division based on the sectional maps contained in 'The National Atlas of the United States of America®' published by the USGS in 1970. The 1:2,000,000-scale Digital Line Graph (DLG) data were merged into a single national hydrography coverage. Where necessary to effect the merge, alignment changes were made. The names were taken from the USGS Topographic 1:100,000-scale maps. For Alaska, the names were taken from the USGS Topographic 1:250,000-scale maps. State lines across water bodies were removed from the national coverage. State attributes were assigned to the features.
Some spatial features were added and corrected. Some name attributes were added or corrected. All occurrences of St. were changed to Saint. Extra spaces were removed from the attributes. Hydrographic features for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands were added. A minor adjustment was made to the shoreline in Galveston Bay, Texas. The linear water feature attribute value, Intercoastal waterway, was changed to Intracoastal waterway.

The following steps were performed by Esri: Downloaded the compressed file from the National Atlas of the United States® and extracted it. Removed unneeded attributes. Removed all records except those with FEATURE attribute types of "Aqueduct", "Braided Stream", "Canal", "Canal Intermittent", "Dam", "Falls", "Intracoastal Waterway", "Stream", and "Stream Intermittent". Reduced the attribute widths of FEATURE and NAME. Added attribute MILES and calculated its values. Created ArcGIS® layer file (.lyr), projection file (.prj), and spatial indices.

The following steps were performed by Esri: Removed Alaskan water feature lines west of 180 degrees longitude. Clipped the water feature lines to the coastline of 2006 U.S. States using ArcGIS Intersect. Dissolved on all attributes to restore connectivity across state boundaries since the Intersect cut the features there. Converted the data set to SDC. Created ArcGIS® layer file (.lyr), projection file (.prj), and spatial indices.

The following steps were performed by Esri: Selected all occurrences of the Santiam River in Oregon and corrected it from 'Santium'. Converted the data set to SDC. Created ArcGIS® layer file (.lyr), projection file (.prj), and spatial indices.

horizpa.horizpar: The geospatial part of this data set was originally extracted from the individual 1:2,000,000-scale State boundary Digital Line Graph (DLG) files produced by the U.S. Geological Survey which have a positional accuracy of 1,720 meters. It was updated several times using various sources whose horizontal positional accuracies are unknown.

dataqual.logic: The shapefile is converted to SDC (Smart Data Compression) format using tools in ArcGIS. The SDC data set is then imported into a file geodatabase to verify, validate, and if needed repair the geometry.
dataqual.complete: After processing, the data set is checked for drawing display and number of records and file sizes compared with source materials. Data completeness generally reflects the content of the original Digital Line Graph (DLG) files.
